John Strode returns to an empty home, starts yelling at his wife who isn’t even there, and walks into a dark basement. Hmmm… I wonder if he’s about to get killed. He sees the washing machine running where he finds Michael’s bloody laundry. Look Mikey, I know this was your home 30 years ago, but you can’t just barge in and do laundry. Michael walks up behind John and impales him on the breaker, electrocuting him and eventually causing his head to explode!

Well you couldn’t do anything scary, but I guess you’ll make up for it with the most over-the-top death scene imaginable? Not cutting it.

Anyway, in a shocking turn of events at the town Halloween party, Simms is a creep too. Yep, as he’s hosting the party on the campus lawn, he keeps asking Tim about Beth’s sexual habits.

However, when he finds out Tim lives at the Myers’ house, he wants to do a radio show live from there. Tim and Beth go back to the house, but Simms is killed in his car by Myers. I’m not exactly sure why he’s killed, but the movie needed a body count, so chalk up another one in that column. We later see his corpse fall from a tree, meaning somehow Michael Myers subtly walked through the hundreds of party goers, climbed a tree, put the body up there, got back down, and walked away without anyone noticing. Sure. That’s believable.

Back at the Myers’ house, Tim and Beth are all alone in a dark house and decide to have sex, assuming that Simms was just pranking them about the whole radio show idea. They insist of having sex in Kara’s room for no reason in particular, which would be just about the strangest thing in any given movie but doesn’t even crack the Top 10 in this one. This is obviously so the whole voyeuristic-camera-in-Tommy-Doyle’s-room angle will come into play, but come on. What college-age male insists on having sex in his older sister’s bedroom?

When Kara sees the light on across the street, she calls her home, surprised that only Tim and Beth are there, and not her parents.

Tim is killed in the bathroom after taking a shower, and Kara tries to get Beth to leave the house. However, Beth doesn’t even seem to know who she’s talking to as she calls Kara “Carol.” SERIOUSLY? With all the atrocious editing in this film, you couldn’t edit someone accidentally calling a character “Carol” to “Kara.” Wow. Anyway, the warnings of both Kara and Carol are too late, and Beth is killed by Michael Myers in another incredibly unscary death scene.

At the Halloween party, Tommy runs into Dr. Loomis, who asks “Where’s the baby?” which is obviously just one of the screenwriter’s notes that spilled over into the shooting script. They make their way back to the boarding house and meet up with all the principal characters who aren’t Michael Myers. The Man in Black is sitting with Kara’s son Danny on his lap, because apparently every character in this thing needs to act like a predator, and he’s revealed to be… Dr. Wynn.

Shocked? Of course not. Who else was it gonna be? The old colleague of a hero who is overly-chummy with him, played by a character actor best known for playing villains? I never would have guessed it. Wynn has barely been in this film though, and his scenes have always been drastically shortened, so if you weren’t aware who this character was, I wouldn’t blame you. There’s even a poorly edited reaction shot of Loomis saying “Wynn” just to remind us who he is!

Kara runs upstairs and sees Mrs. Blankenship with the baby, but when she finds out that Blankenship too is a cult member (which was blatantly obvious), she jumps through the glass second-story window.

It’s a movie, though, so of course she is only injured. The movie then awkwardly cuts to Tommy and Loomis standing outside the house where Kara landed, realizing the cult has taken her. Tommy says he feels like he’s been drugged, which Loomis agrees with. Um… why? Were they drugged previously and they just woke up to see everyone gone? Could the movie make this a little clearer please? Obviously they don’t pass out later in the film, so I guess this is what they’re saying.

Tommy then decides to be sensible for once and ask why the cult didn’t just kill them. Hey, you can’t ask that, that’s my job. Loomis gives the answer that “It’s his game, and I know where he wants to play it.” He’s referring to Smith’s Grove, but what sense does this make? While I suppose you could argue that Wynn still thinks he can convince Loomis to join him in his cult, what good is he doing by keeping Tommy Doyle alive? If they did drug Tommy and Loomis, why didn’t they capture them and lock them up at Smith’s Grove? Absolutely nothing in this film makes sense.

In another scene that was clearly edited down to the point of total incoherence, Dr. Loomis meets up with Dr. Wynn in his office.

When Loomis asks for an explanation of his actions, Wynn says “I’ve had my failures, but this baby —Jamie’s baby. We are in the dawn of a new age, Sam.” He then has Dr. Loomis knocked unconscious. That’s the entire explanation. What does he want with the baby? Doesn’t he run the cult that controls Michael Myers? Doesn’t Michael Myers have to kill off every member of his family? Why is he waxing eloquent about this baby like it’s the Antichrist or something? I thought he wanted to kill it. I have watched this exchange over and over, and nothing makes any sense. I suppose the failures are other times he’s tried to artificially inseminate someone? Maybe that’s what he did with Jamie? OK… Michael is ultimate evil, and he’s trying to create more ultimate evil by forcing Michael’s relative to have children. That would make sense if Michael’s entire goal (and the goal of the cult) wasn’t to kill his entire family. Had no one working on this ever seen a Halloween film… or a horror film… or a film? The movie is working against itself!

Meanwhile, Tommy is wandering through the hospital, trying to find Kara. He walks right into the MAXIMUM SECURITY WARD which isn’t locked.

Why is the cult running their operations out of a hospital if they’re not even going to lock the doors leading to MAXIMUM SECURITY? Tommy finds Kara locked in Room 237, which means that shockingly someone on the production team had actually seen a horror film before, and he breaks her out and they try to outrun Michael Myers. Why does the cult have Kara captured? Oh don’t worry, they won’t answer that either. If it’s for more of that breeding ultimate evil crap, how will that work? She’s not related to Michael! I mean, her dad was a real jerk, but I don’t think they can make a race of superhuman killers out of those genes.

Wynn goes back to do perform some surgery (I guess it’s some experimental stuff, but who knows, it may be a tonsillectomy), with Jamie’s baby and Danny locked in the next room. Tommy and Kara save the children, because this isn’t Halloween 3 and we’re not killing kids. Michael for… reasons… kills Wynn and all the doctors/cult members.

I’m so glad that plot went absolutely nowhere. The editing and strobe light effects in the operating room massacre scene are so unpleasant that they render it near unwatchable (not that it really was to begin with).

Kara and Tommy get chased by Myers around the hospital for way too long, and finally it seems that Tommy kills him. There have at least been great chase scenes in each of these movies so far, but nope, this one is boring as sin. For some reason Tommy is the one who delivers the final blow to Michael Myers, as opposed to our strong, interesting female lead, and everyone gets away. Outside of Smith’s Grove, Tommy is driving everyone home and offers to take Loomis with him, but he says he has some business to conclude.

That doesn’t really make any sense, but why start doing that now? We see the Michael Myers mask laying on the floor where his body used to be, and we hear Loomis scream from inside. The End.

Wow. I am in utter shock at how butchered this movie is. Even if you went in not knowing a single thing about production, you could tell within 5 seconds that this thing was edited beyond recognition. What were they thinking? Well according to Marianne Hagan, the R-rated film was screened to a bunch of 13 or 14-year-olds who were bored. You have to be 17 to get into an R-rated film by yourself! This is not your test audience. However, by reshoots, Donald Pleasence was dead, so they had to work the new ending around that, which is why he’s barely in it.

Think for one second about the single worst film you’ve ever seen. What is it? The Room? Birdemic? The Garbage Pail Kids Movie? It may have character motivations and plot points that don’t make sense, but can you trace the story from the beginning to the end? Does it have an arc? Is there some kind of resolution at the end? Johnny kills himself and Mark leaves Lisa, the birds fly away (albeit without much reason), and the Garbage Pail Kids… find acceptance? I can’t remember, but it made more sense than this. The Curse of Michael Myers sets up characters and arcs that go nowhere, and even worse, contradict the other ones. Myers isn’t dead at the end, Loomis might or might not be, we have no idea if any of the cult members are alive somewhere, the idea that Kara’s son could be evil is still open-ended… you get the point. I cannot think of another film, at least one released by a major studio on a $5 million budget, that was so incompetent at telling a story. The only one I can think of is Manos: The Hands of Fate, which was made on a budget of $19,000 by a bunch of people who never worked in film. This is unacceptable. In terms of storytelling, I don’t think I’ve ever seen a worse film.

Story (0/25 Points)

Nope. It doesn’t get a single point. It’s entirely incoherent and contradicts itself.

Characters (7/25 Points)

I actually like Kara Strode as a character, and Marianne Hagan is really trying her best, but beyond that… ugh. Dr. Loomis has his time significantly cut, and Jamie is played by a different actress (who does OK, I guess) and is gone after a few minutes. The other performances are mostly just bizarre from Paul Rudd’s weird choices as Tommy Doyle to the comically over-the-top Mrs. Blankenship and John Strode. Mitchell Ryan adds very little as Dr. Wynn, and while I do believe Kim Darby as abused wife Debra Strode, she gets killed off too early to make an impression.

Experience (0/25 Points)

The editing is some of the worst I’ve ever seen, constantly cutting away from a scene and back again for no reason. Also, strobe lights aren’t scary, and the loud score rips away what could be moments of subtlety. It is clear to any viewer that this movie was ruined on the cutting room floor.

Originality (2/25 Points)

It kind of throws a bunch of cliches at you and doesn’t add them together for any kind of effect. I don’t really count “absolute gibberish” as original.

FINAL SCORE: 9%

I was not expecting it to be this bad. I don’t know if the producer’s cut is going to be good, but I can’t imagine it’s any worse than this.

MATCH-UP HOME

HOME

Year: 1989

Director: Dominique Othenin-Girard

Starring: Donald Pleasence, Danielle Harris, Ellie Cornell

After the shocking twist ending to the otherwise underwhelming Halloween 4, everyone wondered where the next sequel would go now that Jamie Lloyd (Danielle Harris) was a killer. Would she and her uncle Michael Myers team up to kill? Was he dead for good and she would be the lone killer? Well, no, none of that happened. Producer Moustapha Akkad decided that a child couldn’t be a killer, also believing that fans would be upset at another Halloween film without Michael Myers so the idea was scrapped.

That said, this movie doesn’t completely ignore that final scene. It turns out that Jamie only attacked and injured her foster mother, but didn’t kill her. Since we never actually saw the murder, I suppose I have to let this go. Jamie has been in a children’s mental hospital ever since, getting treatment for attacking her foster mother and for her continuing nightmares of Michael Myers.

The psychic link she was suggested to have with her uncle before is played up something fierce here, and it’s actually built on nicely. Again, Danielle Harris gives one of the best performances in the film as the traumatized Jamie. She’s a mute for the first half of the film, which she gradually gets over, and she has a close bond with her foster sister Rachel (Ellie Cornell) and even Rachel’s housemates Tina and Samantha (Wendy Kaplan, Tamara Gylnn). Dr. Loomis (Donald Pleasence) also checks in on her, worried himself that Michael Myers (Don Shanks) will return.

Meanwhile, the movie has to retcon how Michael Myers survived being blown away by multiple people at the end of the last film. Yep, he somehow survived the blast and managed to crawl away to safety, even though in this film it’s shown that the police set dynamite to the area as well (something filmed for but not shown in Halloween 4). Myers finds safety at the lodge of a hobo who takes him in and nurses him back to health… for some reason.

This hobo also apparently has a parrot, because of course he does. Did he just leave his modest, lonely abode one day and walk into a pet store? Does he continue to walk into this pet store and buy birdseed? He’s not even that good of a hobo if he lives this close to a suburban community.

Apparently, an earlier version of this scene was shot with some sort of occult overtones and a man who raises Myers from the dead, but this was shelved. I mean, it would have added forced supernatural themes into a movie that is about a human killer (Yeah, we’ll get to the 6th film), but at least it would have made sense.

Anyway, on Halloween Eve, Michael kills the hobo, because this guy’s not exactly Kato Kaelin when it comes to being a decent house guest, and he makes his return to Haddonfield. Jamie, through her psychic link to her uncle, can see him killing the hobo. Her nurse (Betty Carvalho) tries to help her with her problems, but unfortunately giving the single worst performance in the movie gets in the way.

Her acting is just so over-the-top, shouting every word like it’s some daytime soap opera. I know it’s an incredibly minor performance, but it’s just awful.

It’s not explicitly stated if Rachel, Tina and Samantha are sorority sisters or even in college, but regardless, they all live in a pretty nice house together. Rachel returns home, and Jamie starts to worry that Michael Myers is near the house. The buildup here is genuinely suspenseful, with Michael Myers stalking his victims in a creepy way he hasn’t done since the original film.

Rachel eventually runs out of the house and manages to call the police, showing us the film is not afraid to take its time. It helps that the additional music by Alan Howarth really does a nice job of blending in with the existing Halloween theme by John Carpenter.

When the police do get there, they are the two most stereotypical bumbling cops imaginable. There’s even cartoon music and sound effects that accompany them! WHAT? Was the editor suddenly self-aware of how idiotic these characters were that he threw this in? We follow up the tense scene where Rachel is in fear of getting murdered with something out of a Mel Brooks movie. It’s weird.

After the guys from Lethally Stupid Weapon leave, Rachel goes back into the house and gets murdered. OK, that’s the quick version, because once again, there is actually good buildup to it, and we genuinely don’t know if it’s going to happen or not. Again, this kind of suspense and surprise has not existed since the first film. I agree with the majority of viewers that killing off one of the most likable characters from the last film and leaving her annoying friends Tina and Samantha isn’t a great decision, but it’s still an effective scene, even (or especially) in broad daylight.

Very little is actually shown of her scissors-to-the-chest death, leaving a lot to the imagination. Instead, we see Jamie violently convulsing, because she knows it’s happening.

Beau Starr returns as Sheriff Ben Meeker, who is far more on edge this time around, but understandably so. His daughter was killed during the last murder spree, and Meeker himself seemingly blasted Michael Myers into oblivion. Again, in time, he does heed the warnings of Dr. Loomis.

Meeker’s first scene with Loomis gives us one of the best Loomis quotes of the whole series, “I prayed that [Michael] would burn in Hell, but in my heart, I knew that Hell would not have him.” It’s amazing that Loomis pretty much does the same thing in every film, and yet it never gets old or feels repetitive. That’s the brilliant acting of Donald Pleasence for you. That said, like in Halloween II, Loomis is more unhinged here, but if you thought a murderer had been killed twice, wouldn’t you be?

Unfortunately, with one of the most likable characters dead and our child protagonist still stuck in the hospital, the film goes off the rails for a bit. We have to spend way too much time with Samantha and Tina and their boyfriends Spitz (That’s the only name he’s given) and… this guy.

Bowzer from Sha Na Na would complain this guy is too over the top! It’s like this thing had two screenwriters, one of which was writing a genuine film and one of which was writing a broad parody. Were there really that many ’50s greasers in late ’80s Illinois? Is this town so small they didn’t get the ’50s until the ’80s? Do we get some Vietnam protesters in the next film? What does Tina see in this guy anyway? He only seems to be sexually attracted to his own car. He’s so into it that it makes the guys from “Greased Lightning” seem like they just have a minor crush. In a later scene, Tina gives a terrible speech to Jamie about how Mikey (that’s really what he goes by) makes her feel, even though he’s nothing but a horrible person to her in the entirety of his screen time.

Anyway, Bowzer gets killed soon after by a scythe to the face, (although I would have personally preferred they just forced him to host a lousy Hollywood Squares reboot) and Michael Myers steals his Halloween costume and drives to pick-up Tina for a party. In a scene that takes forever, Tina does not realize it’s Michael Myers behind the mask (Get it? It’s funny because she calls him Michael.).

When they pull off at a gas station for cigarettes, it leads to one of the film’s most infamous moments. Through her psychic connection, Jamie can see that Tina is in trouble and manages to get a few words out like “store” and “big woman,” describing a large advertisement out front of a woman with cookies covering her breasts. She then cries out “cookie woman,” leading Donald Pleasence to repeat it in utter confusion. Regardless, it does lead the cops to Tina, but someone should have done a re-write on this scene.

The scenes at the Halloween party are pretty bland and predictable. Samantha and Spitz have sex. Think they get killed by Michael Myers? Of course they do. Is it scary? Of course it isn’t. Do kids play a prank on the cops where they pretend to be Michael Myers? Of course. Is it funny? Of course it isn’t. Does it go on far too long? Of course it does.

Jamie makes her way to the party with her friend Billy, afraid that everyone is in danger, and Myers begins to chase her and Billy in a car.

Tina sacrifices herself so Jamie and Billy can get to safety, leaving none of the main teenage characters alive.

Dr. Loomis has a plan to take down Michael Myers for good (at least until the next movie), and Jamie Lloyd agrees to help out. Loomis uses Jamie as bait to lure Michael to his old family home. Hold up. THIS was the Myers’ home in the original film.

THIS is the Myers’ home in Halloween 5: The Revenge of Michael Myers.

This sudden and complete switch is a practice dating back to the earliest days of the theatre called “Not Giving a Damn.” However, if you can get past this, the scenes in the Myers’ home are chilling. Like the first act, we’re back to that minimalist horror style of the first film.
